nexttext:
if this limit exits, where $|A \cap n| = |A \cap \{1,2, \cdots, n\}|$ for any $n \in \mathbb{N}$. A finitely additive measure defined on $\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N})$ extending the asymptotic density is called a density measure, and let us denote the set of all density measures by $\mathcal{C}$. 
In general, if a finitely additive probability measure space $(\mathbb{N}, \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N}), \mu)$ are given, one can obtain a normalized positive linear functional $\varphi$ on $l^{\infty}$ of the Banach space of all real-valued bounded functions on $\mathbb{N}$ by the integral with respect to $\mu$. Oppositely, If a normalized positive linear functional $\varphi$ on $l^{\infty}$ is given, we get a finitely additive probability measure $\mu$ on $\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N})$ by $\mu(A) = \varphi(I_A)$, where $I_A$ is the characteristic function of $A \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N})$. In what follows, we will identify these two notions accordingly.
 
  It is known that the linear functionals corresponding to the density measures are precisely the linear functionals that extend Ces\`{a}ro mean ([7, Theorem 3.3]). Namely, it consists of those functionals $\varphi$ for which
holds if this limit exists. We will deal with a certain class of such linear functionals satisfying the following condition:

In general, if a finitely additive probability measure space $(\mathbb{N}, \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{N}), \mu)$ are given, one can obtain a normalized positive linear functional $\varphi$ on $l^{\infty}$ of the Banach space of all real-valued bounded functions on $\mathbb{N}$ by the integral with respect to $\mu$. In what follows, we will identify these two notions accordingly.

We denotes by $\tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ the set of all such density measures.  In [6] we have investigated the space $\tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ and proved that it is a weak-$^*$ compact subset of $\mathcal{C}_0$ and $ex(\mathcal{C}_0) \subset \tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ holds [6, Theorem 2.1], where $ex(\mathcal{C}_0)$ denotes the extreme points of $\mathcal{C}_0$. prevtext: where $\mathcal{U}$ is any free ultrafilter on $\mathbb{N}$ and the limit above is the limit of $f$ along an ultrafilter $\mathcal{U}$ (See [5] for more details of this notion). We denotes by $\tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ the set of all such density measures.  In [6] we have investigated the space $\tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ and proved that it is a weak-$^*$ compact subset of $\mathcal{C}_0$ and $ex(\mathcal{C}_0) \subset \tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ holds [6, Theorem 2.1], where $ex(\mathcal{C}_0)$ denotes the extreme points of $\mathcal{C}_0$. This means that by the Krein-Milman theorem each density measure $\varphi$ in $\mathcal{C}_0$ can be expressed in the form
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\varphi(f)=\int_{\tilde{\mathcal{C}_{0}}}\phi(f)d\mu(\phi),\quad f\in l^{\infty}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>φ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mover accent="true"><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒞</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover></msub><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>∈</mo><msup><mi>l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msup></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $[t+s]$ denotes the largest integer not exceeding $t+s$. We use the following notations for the orbit of $\eta$ in $\Omega^*$ for $\phi^s$: $o_+(\eta) = \{\phi^s(\eta) : s \ge 0\}, \ o_-(\eta) = \{\phi^{-s}(\eta) : s \ge 0\}$
, $o(\eta) = \{\phi^s(\eta) : s \in \mathbb{R}\}$. Furthermore we denote the closures in $\Omega^*$ of these orbits by $\overline{o}_+(\eta), \overline{o}_-(\eta), \overline{o}(\eta)$, respectively. Also we use similar notations for the orbit of $\omega$ in $\mathbb{N}^*$ for $\tau$:  $o_+(\omega) = \{\tau^n \omega : n =0,1,2, \cdots.\}, \ o_-(\omega) = \{\tau^{-n} \omega : n=0,1,2, \cdots.\}, \ o(\omega) = \{\tau^n \omega : n \in \mathbb{Z} \}$, and also $\overline{o}_+(\omega), \overline{o}_-(\omega), \overline{o}(\omega)$ represents their closures in $\mathbb{N}^*$ respectively. 

\medskip
Arguments after section 3 is developed by using the following result which gives a certain expression to the elements of $\tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$. See [6] for a proof.

\begin{thm}
Let $\Omega^*$ be as above, and $\tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ be equipped with the weak-$^*$ topology. We define the mapping $\Phi: \Omega^* \rightarrow \tilde{\mathcal{C}_0}$ as follows: Let $\eta = (\omega, t) \in \Omega^*$ and $\theta = 2^t$, and let us denote the density measure $\Phi(\eta)$ by $\nu_{\eta}$, then we set

},t\in[0,1])," display="block"><mrow><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mi>s</mi></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>τ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></msup><mi>ω</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>∈</mo><msup><mi>ℕ</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>,</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

Also we use similar notations for the orbit of $\omega$ in $\mathbb{N}^*$ for $\tau$:  $o_+(\omega) = \{\tau^n \omega : n =0,1,2, \cdots.\}, \ o_-(\omega) = \{\tau^{-n} \omega : n=0,1,2, \cdots.\}, \ o(\omega) = \{\tau^n \omega : n \in \mathbb{Z} \}$, and also $\overline{o}_+(\omega), \overline{o}_-(\omega), \overline{o}(\omega)$ represents their closures in $\mathbb{N}^*$ respectively.

\begin{thm}

\mathbb{N})" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>ν</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mrow><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="12.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">𝒫</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ℕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: For any $\eta^{\prime} \in o_-(\eta)$ since $\nu_{\eta^{\prime}} \ll \nu_{\eta}$, it follows that
mathml:

u_{\eta}(A_{i})=
u_{\eta}(B)" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>η</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>η</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

u}_{\eta}(\cup_{i=1}^{\infty}\overline{%
A}_{i})=\hat{
u}_{\eta}(\overline{B})" display="inline"><mrow><mi/><mo>⟺</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ν</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>η</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>∪</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ν</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>η</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex39.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\Longleftrightarrow\hat{
u}_{\eta}(\overline{B}\setminus(\cup_{i%
=1}^{\infty}\overline{A}_{i}))=0." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>⟺</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ν</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>η</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>∖</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>∪</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Also $\nu_{\eta^{\prime}}(A_i \setminus B) = 0$ holds for each $i \ge 1$. Then it follows that
prevtext: For any $\eta^{\prime} \in o_-(\eta)$ since $\nu_{\eta^{\prime}} \ll \nu_{\eta}$, it follows that
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex40.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\hat{
u}_{\eta^{\prime}}(\overline{B}\setminus(\cup_{i=1}^{\infty}\overline{A%
}_{i}))=0\Longleftrightarrow\lim_{i}
u_{\eta^{\prime}}(A_{i})=
u_{\eta^{%
\prime}}(B)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>ν</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><msup><mi>η</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>B</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>∖</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo>∪</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>A</mi><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>i</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>⟺</mo><mrow><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><msup><mi>η</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><msup><mi>η</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: for each $i \ge 1$. Also we have that
prevtext: Also $\nu_{\eta^{\prime}}(A_i \setminus B) = 0$ holds for each $i \ge 1$. Then it follows that
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex41.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\nu(A_{i}\setminus B)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\nu_{\phi^{-s}\eta}(A_{i}\setminus B)d%
\mu(s)=0" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>ν</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>∖</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mrow><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>∖</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>

prevtext: for each $i \ge 1$. Also we have that

u(B)" display="inline"><mrow><mi>ν</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

u_{\phi^{-s}\eta}(A_{i})d\mu(s)=\lim_%
{i}
u(A_{i})." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mrow><msup><mi>ϕ</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo movablelimits="false">lim</mo><mi>i</mi></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>ν</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>A</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
has the additive property, where $0 \le c_i \le 1, i=1,2, \cdots, m$ with $\sum_{i=1}^m c_i =1$.
\end{thm}
